name: gusli
definition: Gusli is the oldest Russian multi-string plucked instrument, belonging to the zither family, due to its strings being parallel to its resonance board.
description:
Gusli exact history is unknown. Is possible to be imported from Western and Central Europe during the Middle Ages, when the zither had immense popularity.

It is also related to such ancient instruments as Chinese guzheng which has a thousand-year history and its Japanese relative koto.

Folk gusli have from 11 to 36 gut or metal strings, tuned diatonically. There are two main forms: helmet-shaped and wing-shaped.

Gusli is plucked, not hammered. In that functional sense, it has more relationship to a harp or zither than to a hammer dulcimer.

Gusli has a strong, resonant, sweet and even silvery sound.

Its amplitude depends on how hard the string is plucked, its pitch is high, with the sound having long duration if not interfered with.

The gusli is most often played upright, with the edge of the long end down on the knees; the left hand damps the strings not in the chord/melody, while the right hand strums or plucks the strings.

featured.caption:
Wing-shaped gusli is much smaller and has more resemblance to Baltic psaltery.

It is held much more like modern guitars.
